newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian tourism to lure young Japanese women.
newsitem.headline: Australian tourism to lure young Japanese women.

text.p: Australia on Monday announced plans to tempt more young Japanese "office ladies" to its shores and halt a slide in Australia's share of the huge Japanese tourism market.

The official Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) said it and four Australian and Japanese airlines would spend a total of A$10 million in an advertising and marketing campaign aimed at Japan's young, experienced female travellers.
"This is one of Australia's core segments, accounting for more than 20 percent of travel from Japan," the ATC said.
The ATC, funded by the government, said it was supported in the campaign by Australia's Qantas Airways Ltd and Ansett as well as Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways.

Australia's share of the Japanese market has been slipping in recent years, with Japanese travellers preferring instead to make one last trip to colonial Hong Kong, shop in Italy or place a bet in the casinos of Las Vegas, the ATC said.
Australia A$16 billion tourism industry, the nation's most lucrative export industry, is keen to arrest the decline.
"Without winning back this experienced female segment, which is the only underperforming one, we are not going to achieve this," said Tony Virili, the ATC's regional director for Japan.

The ad campaign begins in earnest next January in Japanese media and will be aimed at women aged between 20 and 34 years who have "bought their Gucchi and Prada bags" and now want a place to relax and "be themselves", Virili told Reuters.
Japanese tourists account for one fifth of all visitors to Australia.
